etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Benjamin Smart (d. 1872), elocutionist and grammarian. From nucleus + -iform

definitions: Having the form of a nucleus or kernel; of a rounded shape. Also Botany: (especially of the apothecia of certain lichens) globose.
Designating a type of prehistoric stone tool, usually with a rounded working edge, which resembles a knapped core.
